abstract.para: Describes the Hotelling Feature proposed for inclusion in &sipxecs; version &sipxrelease;.

section.title: Overview
section.para: The Hotelling feature provides for defining a set of 'hotel' phones whose features and lines are temporarily reconfigured for a user when that user checks in to the phone. The reconfiguration is reversed either when the user explicitly signs out or after some system-configured elapsed time.

The motivation for this feature is to support environments in which some users are mobile, so a larger population of users can be supported using a smaller number of phones, while preserving the personalization of phone settings and capabilities specific for each user.

section.title: Typical User Scenario
section.para: The following scenario illustrates how the hotelling feature is used. This section is intended only as an example; it is not intended to show all aspects of the Hotelling feature set. Subsequent sections more fully define the requirements.

Our example scenario takes place in an office of JumboExample Corp (a member of the Example family of companies). JumboExample has many field operatives that spend most of thier time away from the office, but each has an occasional need to come in to file reports, attend staff meetings, and be briefed on changes in JumboExample policies. Joe Schmoe is one of these field operatives.

blockquote.para: Joe arrives at the office on Monday morning, and goes to the Field Operative section, where there are 15 cubicles available for operatives when they are in the facility. Each cubicle is supplied with furniture, basic office supplies, a laptop docking station with large screen monitor, and a SIP phone.

Joe goes down the line of cubicles, past a few that are occupied by other field operatives, until he finds one that appears to be available. Before sitting down, he checks the display on the SIP phone and sees that the phone display indeed indicates that no one is presently checked in to this phone (see ).

Joe sits down, puts his laptop in the docking station and the picture of his dog on the desk, and then checks in to the phone. The phone in this cubicle is equipped with several speed dial buttons, one of which is labeled "Checkin". He presses this button and after one ring the call is answered by the checkin autoattendant. The autoattendant prompts him for his personal extension number, which he enters, and it then prompts him for his PIN, he enters the same PIN he uses for voicemail. After a brief pause, the autoattendant confirms that his checkin is successful and instructs him to hang up the phone and wait for it to be reconfigured. Joe hangs up and goes to get coffee (and to see if anyone has left unwanted sweets at the coffee station).

A moment after Joe leaves the cubicle, the phone reboots (see ). When he returns, the first line on the phone is displaying that it is now his extension number, and the message waiting dispay indicates that he has 2 new voicemail messages.

Joe presses the 'Messages' key on the phone to connect to his mailbox, enters his PIN, and deals with the messages. Then he uses the first speed dial key, which is now programmed to the number for the administrative assistant for his team. The assistant answers and preempts his question about where the staff meeting is to be held today: she knew from her caller-id display that it was Joe, and he always calls to ask. Other speed dial keys on the phone are programmed for his home number and that of his supervisor.

While he is reading his email, his supervisor calls: to call him, she had just dialled his extension number, not needing to know which cubicle he had selected. She wants him to meet with her at the end of the day to go over sales projections in his area for the coming month.

Before leaving at the end of the day, Joe repacks his laptop and photo, and presses the speed dial key that is programmed to check him out. The system answers the call and plays an acknowlegement message, but Joe is already on his way home. After a moment, the call disconnects and the phone reboots. When it comes back up, it is again displaying that it is an unassigned phone.

section.title: Requirements
section.para: The fundamental goal of the Hotelling feature is to make using a Hotel phone as much like using a normally assigned phone as possible. A user that has a normally assigned phone should find a Hotel phone as familiar as possible.

section.title: Hotel Phone Identity
section.para: The one difference between a normal user phone and a Hotel phone is that a Hotel phone has an identity of its own that is not associated with the user. In some (possibly most) phones, this additional identity is visible as an additional 'line' on the phone. When no user is checked in to the phone, this hotel phone identity is the only identity associated with the phone (see ). The hotel phone identity is not an extension: it is an internal &sipxecs; identifier, so there is no normal way to dial a Hotel phone when there is no user checked in to it.

section.title: Unassigned Hotel Phones
section.para: A phone that does not have a user checked in has only its hotel phone identity. The display name for the hotel phone identity is a fixed string that is identical for any hotel phone; it is localizable value meant to convey that the phone does not have a user checked in (for example, in English it might be "Open", "Unused", or "Available").

If the phone has speed dial capability, an unassigned hotel phone has a speed dial configured for the 'checkin' service (see ). If the phone supports multiple speed dials, then additional speed dial destinations may be configured for a hotel phone using the same interface available for configuring speed dials for other users; these additional destinations are configured after the automatically configured checkin speed dial destination.

The privileges associated with a hotel phone identity are configurable using the same mechanisms that are available to configure user privileges. The default privileges for a Hotel phone are very restricted:

listitem.para: No PSTN calls (other than an emergency number) are allowed.
No voicemail is allowed (this cannot be changed).
The autoattendant dial-by-name directory does not include any unassigned Hotel phones.

section.title: Checkin
section.para: A system-defined dial sequence is used to "check in" to a hotel phone. This destination is configured as a speed dial on an unassigned phone if the phone supports speed dial (see . This dial sequence connects to the Hoteldesk service:

step.para: The hoteldesk service checks to see if the calling identity is that of an unassigned Hotel phone. If not, an audio message is played that informs the user that checkin is not available from the phone they are using; after the message is complete, the hoteldesk service hangs up the call.

If the calling phones identity is that of an assigned Hotel phone (one that some user is currently checked in to), then an audio prompt is played that indicates that the phone is currently in use and offers to reconfigure the phone for a new user. If the user responds that reconfiguration is desired, the sequence continues as if the phone were unassigned; if not, the hoteldesk service hangs up the call.
An audio prompt is played instructing the user to enter their extension, followed by the pound sign (#).
The entered extension is checked to see if it is that of a user in the system; if not, a message indicating this is played, and this step is repeated.
An audio prompt is played instructing the user to enter their PIN, followed by the pound sign (#).
The entered PIN is checked to see if it is that of the selected user; if not, a message indicating this is played, and the previous step (prompting for the extension) is repeated.

If the PIN was correct, an audio message is played indicating that the checkin has been accepted, the length of time for which it will be in effect (see ), and instructing the user to hang up and await reconfiguration of the phone.
After the user disconnects the call, the phone is reconfigured (see ).

section.title: Reconfiguration Process
section.para: When a user has successfully checked in (see ), the hoteldesk service causes a new configuration to be generated for the phone that adds the configuration specific to the user. The phone is then told to use this new configuration.
See for discussion of how the user-specific configuration and the phone-specific configuration are combined to create the configuration of the checked-in hotel phone.

Similarly, when the user checks out (see ), or the checkin period expires (see ), the hoteldesk service causes a new configuration to be generated for the phone as an unassigned phone (see ), and the phone is instructed to use this new configuration.
For all currently supported phones, reconfiguration requires that the phone reboot.

section.title: Checkout
section.para: A system-defined dial sequence is used to "check out" of a hotel phone. This destination is configured as a speed dial if the phone supports speed dial and is unassigned (see ). This dial sequence connects to the checkout service:

step.para: The service checks to see if the calling identity is that of an assigned Hotel phone. If not, an audio message is played that informs the user that checkout is not available from the phone they are using; after the message is complete, the hoteldesk service hangs up the call.

If the calling phones identity is that of an assigned Hotel phone (one that some user is currently checked in to), then an audio message is played that indicates that the user is now logged out and instructing the user to hang up the phone to reconfigure.
After the user disconnects the call, the phone is reconfigured (see ).

section.title: Expiration
section.para: The assignment of a hotel phone to a user is temporary: a system configuration parameter determines the maximum duration of a hotel phone assignment. If a user has not checked out from a hotel phone when that time has past, a new configuration as an unassigned hotel phone is generated for the phone, and the phone is reconfigured to that unassigned status.

section.title: Feature Tradeoffs and Restrictions
section.para: Some aspects of the user experience in a &sipxecs; system are implemented entirely in one or more &sipxecs; service processes, others (such as speed dial buttons) are implemented entirely within the phone, and many are some hybrid - dependant on both the phone and the service configuration.

listitem.para: Features that cannot be supported without making changes to &sipxecs; service configurations are not supported.

section.title: Merging User and Phone Configuration
section.para: Phones differ in capability: they may differ, for example, in the number of lines they support, the number of speed dials they support, whether or not they display busy status for lines, and so on. Since some features configured for a user require that specific capabilities be available on the phone, it may be that the configuration for a particular user may not be fully realized on a particular hotel phone. For example, if a user has a large model phone at her 'normal' desk phone, and has configured many speed dial keys, a hotel phone with fewer keys will not be able to display all of those entries.

section.title: Line and Speed Dial Key Assignments
section.para:
Line keys on an assigned hotel phone are allocated in this order:
The identity that the user used to log in to the hotel phone (if the user has a non-hotel phone, this is the line that would normally be the first line on that phone).
If the particular phone requires that a line key be used to configure an additional identity on the phone (most do), then the last key available as a line key is assigned to the hotel phone identity.
Any remaining keys that are available as speed dial entries are used in the order configured for the user.
Additional line keys that are configured on other non-hotel phones assigned to the user are not configured on a hotel phone when the user checks in to it; such lines are configured only for a specific phone, not for the user.
